Pros: The job is easy. I think it's the easiest aerospace job I've ever done.  On-site cafeteria. Plenty of work to keep you busy(usually).  They seem very welcoming for the most part. There might be good long-term opportunities and growth from within.  For the most part, I think they job-flow process runs well, although there's always room to improve.
Cons: The direct hourlys are lazy and unproductive. They seem bitter about low wages, and other petty and menial things. They also don't seem to care about the longevity of the position.  The benefits seem pretty good. I think the wages for the location and job expectations aren't that bad. However, if you need to travel to get there might not work long-term.  The break schedule is very condensed. Takes 2-3 minutes to walk back and forth from the break room, and 2-3 minutes to walk back. You have to be back on time, right on time, or your lead will yell at you. So you have like 2-3 minutes to eat and rest quickly.  The job is very repetitive and monotonous.  The parking situation is a nightmare. It wouldn't be as bad if the dirt lot was paved or better maintained.  OT is sometimes mandatory.  Union environment.
Advice to Management: Right now Zodiac is very concerned with image and production. They make us contractors feel very valued and wanted, and for the most part treat us well.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: This is a new company. Since inception in September 2012, the work and atmosphere is constantly in motion. Because of this, many have risen through the ranks where they wouldn't have otherwise. It is not uncommon to see someone go from entry level to upper management in a short period of time. You will never get bored here. The professional experience comes in dog years - one year here is like seven at another company.
Cons: Not everyone is suited to this type of environment, which is fast-paced and demanding with hard deadlines and multi-million dollar projects on the line. If you are looking for a 'Google' type atmosphere, this is not it. A lot of fresh college grads who expect the world just for showing up from 8:15 to 4:30 are a big source of frustration for the people who actually put in a full day's work.
Advice to Management: Try to establish some normalcy. Emphasize the opportunities. In time the fever-pitch pace will settle. Reward top performers and weed out the laggards.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: There are some great people who work at Zodiac. Many you will understand and can relate to the struggles that you are facing. Great opportunity to learn about your career field and the do's and don'ts of being a supervisor/manager.
Cons: If you like to voice your opinions and do not take no for an answer, this is not the place for you. They expect you to do what they say and not question their requests. Favoritism is rampant at Zodiac. Expect to see some coworkers treated better than others just because they do not stand up for themselves. Also, some supervisors will do everything in their power to undermine you once managers/directors start noticing you and your talent. It's like they despise seeing you grow. There is no such thing as work/life balance here. Managers and supervisors work long hours and expect employees to do the same. This means being on standby by checking your email and answering telephone calls even when you're not working on an urgent project. Some supervisors/managers will also judge you for using your hard earned vacation time, literally, it showed up on my annual review. Avoid the "Zodiac promotion" at all costs. If you're offered a position, ensure that you are presented with a new offer letter before you take on any responsibilities of the new position. If you take on the new responsibilities before an offer letter is signed, you better believe that that offer letter will never come. Also, never accept the first offer. Negotiate!!!
Advice to Management: Stop taking everything so personally. This is a business. Treat your subordinates as employees and not friends. When emotions get in the way, work environments become toxic.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend

Most people are seen as costs rather than investments and the turnover rate shows this to be true. Sort of a feeder for better companies. Morale was pretty low in many locations and solidarity was is short supply (funny for a French company).   They were working on methods for transfer of knowledge and recognized the tribal nature of most current knowledge, but they hadn't fixed it when I left.  I felt bad for production staff as they were treated very poorly and even the experienced skilled ones that the engineers relied on for quality were severely underpaid and under-appreciated.

Cons: First of all, this place is well known for it's low pay across the board. Most of the production labor is hired through the local temp. agency and as a result, people with no skill set are given highly technical and administrative jobs leading to even the simplest tasks becoming a huge battle. Since even the management is poorly paid, nobody seems to have the skills or tries hard enough to promote change. This place is not where you make a career. evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO

Cons: The direct hourlys are lazy and unproductive. They seem bitter about low wages, and other petty and menial things. They also don't seem to care about the longevity of the position.  The benefits seem pretty good. I think the wages for the location and job expectations aren't that bad. However, if you need to travel to get there might not work long-term.  The break schedule is very condensed. Takes 2-3 minutes to walk back and forth from the break room, and 2-3 minutes to walk back. You have to be back on time, right on time, or your lead will yell at you. So you have like 2-3 minutes to eat and rest quickly.  The job is very repetitive and monotonous.  The parking situation is a nightmare. It wouldn't be as bad if the dirt lot was paved or better maintained.  OT is sometimes mandatory.  Union environment.

evaluation: Recommends, Negative Outlook

evaluation: Recommends, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO

Most of the people you work with are awesome people. I don't think I would have lasted as long there had it not been for them.
Cons: We're owned by a French company that doesn't seem to care about anything except turning a profit. They believe the end justifies the means and as long as it looks like we're making money on paper, it doesn't matter how that's achieved. Most of their business decisions leave us in a worse state than before. Removing quality engineers while expecting fewer rejections, outsourcing production and engineering, and agreeing to unreasonable engineering specs. It's a common feature of companies that are too big and whose leaders lose touch with the product. They only care about improving their results before their next career jump. It sucks for everyone else underneath them. My managers are genuinely great people. They have experience and knowledge. They are capable of leading the team and producing excellent results. Unfortunately, through all the damage that corporate has caused, our managers have been severely limited. They have no power to do their job the way they want to.
Advice to Management: This is to the VPs and corporate level people. I understand you live a different life and associate with the wealthier crowd. Your yachts and mansions are more important to you than creating something of true value. When all you seek is to please the share holders so you can get your bonuses, you gut the company. Zodiac Aerospace can be such a huge powerhouse in the industry. We can be 10 times more successful if you had the vision for it. Set up realistic long term goals and invest in the company. It'll pay off greater dividends than whatever you're getting now. Pay your people what they deserve and keep the product in-house. Actually honor your commitments to our customers and don't drop quality just because you think you can shave off a little more profit in the short term. And for goodness' sake, make the work place safer. I see production people sanding in a closed environment without proper masks. All that dust they're breathing in is not healthy. evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: From a mechanical design perspective, the job can be very interesting and varied.  Left to get on with your role with little interference as long as your performance is OK.   Overtime available on most projects, usually when approaching important milestone dates that have to be met.  Providing you do your job well, you accept that the timescales can be sometimes (read mostly) unrealistic, and you don't ruffle any feathers; promotion opportunities are real possibilities.
Cons: The company is very disorganised and inefficient resulting in last minute changes and pressure to push things through in unrealistic timescales. Communication (or lack of) is often a serious issue from the team leads, even within your own project team.  How enjoyable the role is dependant on which project you're moved onto and who is managing/leading the team.   Design methodologies are very disjointed and not coordinated very well. Little control over how internal design standards are managed.  There is a severe shortage of engineers for the amount of work we have so they have to take what they can get. This results in some engineers not capable/motivated in doing the job. This has a knock on effect of other engineers within the team having to take up the slack.  The Catia/SmarTeam system is poorly setup. Not taking the advice of consultants resulting in frustrating performance of the system. System crashes, lost work, extremely slow searches/load times are a common occurrence. Things are changing slowly but not fast enough. With aggressive timescales, this only adds to the pressure.  Lessons are not learned from failings of other projects. It feels like Groundhog Day with project after project requiring engineers to work excessive overtime because another milestone date could be missed due to the same reasons the previous 20 projects almost missed theirs!  Change as a whole is very slow within the company. With some very old school managers stuck in their ways, it's like trying to turn the direction of a big oil tanker in a stormy sea with a small wooden oar.
Advice to Management: Communication is a real issue. This seems to be across the company. It's almost a cultural thing. Not sure how easy this is to eradicate, but I really believe that if this was addressed many problems would go away.
